The first computer virus was created in 1983 and was called the 'Elk Cloner'.
The first 1GB hard drive, introduced in 1980, weighed over 500 pounds and cost $40,000.
The term 'bug' in computer science originated from a real moth found in a computer in 1947 by Grace Hopper.
The world's first website, created by Tim Berners-Lee, is still online and can be visited.
The QWERTY keyboard layout was designed to slow down typing to prevent typewriter jams.
The first computer mouse was made of wood and was invented by Doug Engelbart in 1964.
The original name for Windows 95 was 'Windows 4.0'.
The first programming language was created by Ada Lovelace in the 19th century for Charles Babbage’s Analytical Engine.
The term 'spam' for unwanted email comes from a Monty Python sketch.
The world's first 3D printer was created in 1984 and was called the SLA-1.
A single Google search uses more computing power than the Apollo 11 mission did to land on the moon.
The world's first computer game, 'Tennis for Two', was created in 1958 and displayed on an oscilloscope.
The first hard drive, introduced by IBM in 1956, could hold only 5MB of data.
The concept of a 'debugging' tool was popularized by the story of Grace Hopper removing a moth from a computer.
The first computer password was used by MIT students in the 1960s and was simply a string of letters and numbers.
The programming language 'Python' is named after the Monty Python comedy group, not the snake.
A computer’s CPU speed is measured in gigahertz (GHz), with 1 GHz equating to one billion cycles per second.
The ‘404 Error’ code for a missing webpage is named after the room number where the error was first detected at CERN.
The first smartphone was IBM’s Simon Personal Communicator, which was introduced in 1994.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971 to himself.
The 'Turing Award' is named after Alan Turing, the father of theoretical computer science.
The term 'cloud computing' comes from the practice of using a cloud symbol to represent the internet in diagrams.
The first web browser was called 'WorldWideWeb' and was later renamed to 'Nexus'.
The 'Hello World' program was used to demonstrate the simplicity of new programming languages and concepts.
The programming language 'Java' was originally called 'Oak' after a tree outside the creator’s window.
The first computer bug was a real moth that was discovered in a relay of the Harvard Mark II computer.
The 'Doom' video game was one of the first to use 3D graphics and had a major influence on the gaming industry.
The largest computer chip measures just 1 millimeter across but can contain billions of transistors.
The first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson, and it was a test message that said 'QWERTYUIOP'.
The term 'bit' is short for 'binary digit'.
The first video game console was the Magnavox Odyssey, released in 1972.
The first computer virus to spread in the wild was called 'Brain', created in 1986 in Pakistan and was the work of 2 brothers, Basit and Amjad Farooq Alvi.
The term 'software engineering' was coined in 1968 at a conference on software engineering.
The first computer 'bug' was a moth found in a computer relay by Grace Hopper.
The first commercial computer, the UNIVAC I, was installed in the United States Census Bureau in 1951.
The programming language 'C' was developed in the 1970s and is the basis for many modern programming languages.
The first digital camera, developed by Kodak, was built in 1975 and had a resolution of 0.01 megapixels.
The term 'open source' was coined in 1998 to describe software that is freely available and modifiable.
The first algorithm intended to be processed by a machine was created by Ada Lovelace for Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine.
The first website to offer online shopping was Amazon, which started selling books in 1994.
The first computer graphics were created by a physicist named William Fetter in 1965.
The average computer user will touch the keyboard 2,000 times a day.
The world's first computer-generated animation was created by a computer scientist named Ed Catmull in 1972.
The 'desktop' metaphor used in operating systems like Windows and MacOS was inspired by office workspaces.
The world's first computer game, 'Spacewar!', was created in 1962 by Steve Russell and others at MIT.
The world's first computer mouse was made out of wood and cost around $40 in the 1960s.
The programming language 'Ruby' was named after a gemstone and was developed in the 1990s.
The first computer 'bug' was a moth found in a computer relay by Grace Hopper in 1947.
The 'Turing Test', proposed by Alan Turing in 1950, is used to determine if a machine exhibits intelligent behavior.
The world's first email was sent by Ray Tomlinson in 1971 and was a test message sent to himself.
